title: allow dtype specification in abs2, rms

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Does this improve existing functionality?

labels.name: functionality
labels.description: Does this add new functionality?

body:
#### Reference Issue
 fixes #1656


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
This PR allows a user to specify a target dtype in abs2 and rms calculations.

This resolves the issue with rms calculation on integer inputs noted in #1656 .  For example, if dtype is not specified, we get overflow:

```python
In [14]: x = np.arange(1, 32768, dtype=np.int16)

In [15]: librosa.util.abs2(x)
Out[15]: array([1, 4, 9, ..., 9, 4, 1], dtype=int16)
```

If dtype is specified, we get proper outputs:

```python
In [16]: librosa.util.abs2(x, dtype=np.float32)
Out[16]: 
array([1.00000000e+00, 4.00000000e+00, 9.00000000e+00, ...,
       1.07354522e+09, 1.07361075e+09, 1.07367629e+09], dtype=float32)
```

Float32 is the default for rms now, as the result will be averaged and then sqrt'ed anyway.

#### Any other comments?

I've also snuck in a replacement of `np.abs(S)**2` by `util.abs2(S)` in the rms calculation.  Not sure how we missed that one before, but it's fixed now.

title: Overflow in `feature.rms` when dtype='int16'

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
Edit - I guess this is because you're supposed to only use float with librosa?

```
In [1]: import numpy as np
In [2]: from librosa import feature
In [3]: y = np.random.randint(-32768, 32768, 10000, dtype='int16')
In [4]: feature.rms(y=y, frame_length=256, hop_length=32)
venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/librosa/feature/spectral.py:981: RuntimeWarning: invalid value encountered in sqrt
  return np.sqrt(power)
```

The `RuntimeWarning` is because it's trying to compute the sqrt of a negative (overflowed) number.

title: Regression: bandwidth estimation now requires all vertices to have edges

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
**Describe the bug**

In 0.9 and earlier, the bandwidth for `affinity` mode in recurrence matrix calculation was inferred as the median distance to the k'th nearest neighbor of each data point:
https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/b9830b4a335b1e7e4be66ee81870573bf3d516d0/librosa/segment.py#L524-L526

Because we were using `nanmedian(rec.max(axis=1))`, any empty rows of `rec` would be implicitly ignored in the median calculation.  This, I believe, is a good and correct thing.

After merging #1495 , the behavior has changed:
https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/e18d544cbebfb590da34710ba2de86292179ec39/librosa/segment.py#L1357-L1367

we now explicitly construct an array of the k'th neighbor distance for each point, and then derive bandwidths later on.  If a point does not have any neighbors, an exception is raised.  This is correct and necessary if we're doing individual or pairwise bandwidth estimates (eg `mean_k` or `gmean_k`), but I think the requirement is too strict if we're doing global bandwidth estimation.


**To Reproduce**

Behavior is triggered by our segmentation example in the advanced gallery, resulting in the following:

```
Unexpected failing examples:
/home/bmcfee/git/librosa/docs/examples/plot_segmentation.py failed leaving traceback:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/bmcfee/git/librosa/docs/examples/plot_segmentation.py", line 77, in <module>
    R = librosa.segment.recurrence_matrix(Csync, width=3, mode='affinity',
  File "/home/bmcfee/git/librosa/librosa/segment.py", line 685, in recurrence_matrix
    aff_bandwidth = __affinity_bandwidth(rec, bandwidth, bandwidth_k)
  File "/home/bmcfee/git/librosa/librosa/segment.py", line 1363, in __affinity_bandwidth
    raise ParameterError("The sample at time point {} has no neighbors".format(i))
librosa.util.exceptions.ParameterError: The sample at time point 0 has no neighbors
```

**Expected behavior**

I think that if we're estimating scalar bandwidths, we can support empty rows in the recurrence matrix.  In this case, we can fill in `nan` if the link set is empty, and then use nan-friendly estimators if we're producing a scalar bandwidth.

Does this sound reasonable?  If so, I'll make a quick PR for it.

title: harmonic interpolation for scipy 1.9.3

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: testing
labels.description: Issues with our test design and continuous integration services

body:
#### Reference Issue
Fixes #1595 


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
This PR "fixes" the tests on dynamic multichannel harmonic interpolation that began failing with the release of scipy 1.9.3.

Scare-quotes here are because I've swapped out the interpolation mode from "slinear" to "nearest".  This is okay here because the tests are really just verifying that operating on multiple channels simultaneously provides equivalent output to individual channel processing.

#### Any other comments?

The tests began failing here because spline mode interpolation (eg "slinear") no longer supports repeated values in the domain.  This can happen when reassigned frequencies are not unique within a frame.

Swapping out to "linear" mode fixes that problem, but introduces a new problem wherein the result can be `nan` and this breaks the allclose check.  Rather than hack the allclose check to only verify the finite values, I've swapped over to a nearest-neighbor interpolator here.

I'm okay with this fix for now, but it may be worth thinking carefully about whether we want to build a bit more safety into the frequency reassignment method.

As there are no changes to the code in this PR, I'm okay with merging when CI passes.

labels.name: bug

body:
**Describe the bug**

Our tests are currently failing on scipy 1.9.3, as revealed in this recent PR: #1594 

Specifically, we're getting the following:

```python
=========================== short test summary info ============================
FAILED tests/test_multichannel.py::test_interp_harmonics_multi_vary[test1_44100.wav] - ValueError: Expect x to not have duplicates
FAILED tests/test_multichannel.py::test_salience_multi_dynamic[test1_44100.wav-False] - ValueError: Expect x to not have duplicates
FAILED tests/test_multichannel.py::test_salience_multi_dynamic[test1_44100.wav-True] - ValueError: Expect x to not have duplicates
= 3 failed, 13797 passed, 2 skipped, 494 xfailed, 9583 warnings in 403.14s (0:06:43) =
Error: Process completed with exit code 1.
```

**Expected behavior**
Interp harmonics (and salience) tests should pass without issue independent of numpy version.

These had been working previously, eg this build https://github.com/librosa/librosa/actions/runs/3244858112/jobs/5321598126 used scipy 1.9.1 without issue. 

After skimming the [release notes](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/release.1.9.3.html), I think https://github.com/scipy/scipy/pull/16780 is the cause.  It appears that reassigned_spectrogram is not returning a strictly monotonic sequence for reassigned frequencies, and this breaks the harmonic interpolator in spline mode.  I believe the code here is correct, and only the test needs to be adjusted (eg to use a different example, or a different interp mode).

title: numpy 1.23 compatibility

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: testing
labels.description: Issues with our test design and continuous integration services

body:
**Describe the bug**
We appear to have some fancy-slicing errors with numpy 1.23.  These arise entirely from the new requirement that iterable indices must be tuples (not lists).

For example, this test currently fails on numpy 1.23:

```python
――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― test_sync_multi[2-0-None] ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――

aggregate = None, ndim = 2, axis = 0

    @pytest.mark.parametrize("aggregate", [None, np.mean, np.sum])
    @pytest.mark.parametrize(
        "ndim,axis", [(1, 0), (1, -1), (2, 0), (2, 1), (2, -1), (3, 0), (3, 2), (3, -1), (4, 0), (4, 3), (4, -1)]
    )
    def test_sync_multi(aggregate, ndim, axis):
        data = np.ones([6] * ndim, dtype=np.float)
    
        # Make some slices that don't fill the entire dimension
        slices = [slice(1, 3), slice(3, 4)]
        dsync = librosa.util.sync(data, slices, aggregate=aggregate, axis=axis)
    
        # Check the axis shapes
        assert dsync.shape[axis] == len(slices)
    
        s_test = list(dsync.shape)
        del s_test[axis]
        s_orig = list(data.shape)
        del s_orig[axis]
        assert s_test == s_orig
    
        # The first slice will sum to 2 and have mean 1
        idx = [slice(None)] * ndim
        idx[axis] = 0
        if aggregate is np.sum:
            assert np.allclose(dsync[idx], 2)
        else:
>           assert np.allclose(dsync[idx], 1)
E           IndexError: only integers, slices (`:`), ellipsis (`...`), numpy.newaxis (`None`) and integer or boolean arrays are valid indices

tests/test_multichannel.py:70: IndexError

 tests/test_multichannel.py ⨯                             
```
but it would be fixed by saying `dsync[tuple(idx)]`.

I've audited the codebase and all issues are confined to tests (not the library itself), so this should be an easy fix.  PR forthcoming.

title: CI failure on windows with resampy 0.4.1

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: testing
labels.description: Issues with our test design and continuous integration services

labels.name: Upstream/dependency bug
labels.description: Another package is causing us trouble!

body:
**Describe the bug**

This popped up yesterday after releasing resampy 0.4.1.  Our test suite generally works fine, except for one test on windows that's failing.

The relevant part of the error log is

```python
        shape[axis] = int(shape[axis] * sr_new / sr_orig)
    
        if shape[axis] < 1:
>           raise ValueError(
                "Input signal length={} is too small to "
                "resample from {}->{}".format(x.shape[axis], sr_orig, sr_new)
            )
E           ValueError: Input signal length=720200 is too small to resample from 22050->4000
```

Actual build log is here: https://github.com/librosa/librosa/runs/8276453091?check_suite_focus=true

Note that the same test works fine on all other platforms.  Scrolling up the error log, what I'm seeing is:

```python
tests\test_core.py:1880: 
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _
librosa\core\spectrum.py:1591: in iirt
    y_resampled.append(resample(y, orig_sr=sr, target_sr=cur_sr, res_type=res_type))
librosa\core\audio.py:648: in resample
    y_hat = resampy.resample(y, orig_sr, target_sr, filter=res_type, axis=axis)
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _

x = array([0., 0., 0., ..., 0., 0., 0.]), sr_orig = 22050, sr_new = 4000
axis = -1, filter = 'kaiser_best', parallel = False, kwargs = {}
sample_ratio = 0.18140589569160998, shape = [-64134]
```

So it looks like somehow the shape calculation is overflowing and becoming a negative int (?!).  I don't see any what that this makes sense though, as the resulting shape (-64134) is not what you would get be a 16-bit signed integer overflow of the true shape `int(720200 * 4000 / 22050) = 130648`.  At any rate, all numbers in the shape calculation of resampy are Python ints and not numpy ints (up until the division anyway), and this would not overflow in the first place.  So I'm pretty puzzled.

My first instinct was to push this back as a resampy issue, but I don't think there's actually a problem there.  Rather, I think there's something subtly broken in the windows CI environment to trigger this.

As a side note, #1566 would obviate this issue in the tests, but I'd still like to figure out what's going on here.

title: Where does the formula in `window_bandwidth` come from?

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: question
labels.description: Issues asking for help doing something

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: Issues relating to docstrings, examples, and documentation build

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Here's our formula for `window_bandwidth`

```python
        win = get_window(window, n)
        WINDOW_BANDWIDTHS[key] = n * np.sum(win ** 2) / np.sum(np.abs(win)) ** 2
```

This formula is (proportional to) the ratio between the square of the L2 norm and the square of the L1 norm.
I see how this relates to the (inverse) "peakiness" of the window vector, but i'd like some mathematical context around it.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Some explanation in the docstring as to why we use this formula + where it comes from. Maybe a bibliographical /textbook reference.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
* Knowledge of the First Kind
* Knowledge of the Third Kind

https://www.gutenberg.org/files/3800/3800-h/3800-h.htm

**Additional context**
Found while discussing #745

title: fixed off-by-one in yin/pyin difference calculation, fixes #1425

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
#### Reference Issue
Fixes #1425 


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.

This PR implements the correction to yin's autocorrelation noted in #1425.

The only real difference here is the inclusion (exclusion) of the 0th sample per frame in the autocorrelation calculation.  It's a little ambiguous in the yin paper about how this should be handled, though the matlab code does seem to exclude it.  Our previous implementation (0.8 series) included it, and #1425 notes that it can produce some very small frame modulation artifacts in the resulting f0.

I'm not 100% sure I understand this, but I expect it comes down to analyzing a frame of length `win_length+1` and interpreting it as a frame of length `win_length`; the forced padding in the rfft calculations obscured this point for us.

#### Any other comments?

The change in behavior here is quite miniscule, on the order of hundreths of a Hz.  I don't think anyone will be impacted much by this change, but it does stabilize the detection behavior a little bit.

title: Better support for odd frame lengths

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Does this improve existing functionality?

labels.name: API change
labels.description: Does this change the behavior of existing API?

body:
#### Reference Issue
- fixes #1359 
- fixes #1244 
- fixes #1344 


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
This PR implements a number of small fixes to improve support for odd frame lengths in STFT-based analyses:

- `istft` now lets you override the inferred frame length.  Tests confirm that this preserves round-trip reconstruction.  #1244 
- `_spectrogram` helper similarly only infers `n_fft` from the spectrogram if the given `n_fft` (default 2048) does not align to a provided spectrogram shape.  If an odd length is given, but it is compatible with the shape of `S`, then the value is not inferred.  #1359 
- `griffinlim` now passes `n_fft` through to `istft`
- `plp` passes the frame length through to `istft` when inverting the fourier tempogram
- `mel_to_audio` passes frame length to `griffinlim` #1344 

#### Any other comments?

I think this covers all uses of `istft`. The effects module should pass through automatically; cqt always uses an integral power of 2 (even length) for its internal calls.

title: Framing fails with ndim>2

body:
**Describe the bug**
This came up in testing #1351 .  #944 implemented multidimensional framing, and the tests cover the case up to input of 2 dimensions.  However, when ndim is 3 or larger, framing no longer behaves correctly, and pulls garbage in from memory.



**To Reproduce**

```python
>>> import numpy as np
>>> import librosa

>>> # Create a 4d input and slice it down
>>> x4 = np.random.randn(2, 3, 4, 100)
>>> x3 = x4[0]
>>> x2 = x3[0]
>>> x1 = x2[0]

>>> # Frame each version with the same parameters
>>> x4f = librosa.util.frame(x4, 10, 1)
>>> x3f = librosa.util.frame(x3, 10, 1)
>>> x2f = librosa.util.frame(x2, 10, 1)
>>> x1f = librosa.util.frame(x1, 10, 1)

>>> # We should have x1f = x2f[0, :] = x3f[0, 0, :] = x4f[0,0,0, :]
>>> np.allclose(x1f, x2f[0])
True

>>> np.allclose(x1f, x3f[0, 0])
False

False

***BEFORE POSTING A BUG REPORT*** Please look through [existing issues (both open and closed)](https://github.com/librosa/librosa/issues?q=is%3Aissue) to see if it's already been reported or fixed!


**Describe the bug**
The function Trim and Split do not handle multichannel well. All channels are combined into one signal using core.to_mono. This is may be a problem in several types of multichannel signals (for example when the two channels are out of phase). These functions must be updated to allow for each channel's signal to be processed individually.

title: Deemphasis modifies signals in place

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: API change
labels.description: Does this change the behavior of existing API?

body:
**Describe the bug**
Effects.deemphasis performs an in-place subtraction on the first sample of the input signal to handle the initial boundary condition.

It should not do this, and in general we should not modify input signals.

Relatedly, I think the handling of `zi` is incorrect in general, and not actually usable for it's intended purpose of incremental block processing.  This is because there is no way for the user to access the final state `zf` generated by lfilter, and would therefore never have a value to pass in other than `None`.

The obvious solution, I would think, is to pass in zi directly rather than subtract it from y[0] on input. However, doing this with the initial zi we currently use produces incorrect output and does not correctly invert the prermphasis filter.

I'd be curious for opinions on the best way around this: @lostanlen any thoughts?


**Software versions***
0.8.1

title: _spectrogram helper returns incorrect n_fft for odd lengths

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
**Describe the bug**

Much of the `librosa.features` submodule relies upon a helper function `librosa.core.spectrum._spectrogram`, which allows us to easily support both time-domain and time-frequency-domain inputs for spectral features.  When `y` is given but `S` is not, a spectrogram is constructed and returned, along with `n_fft`.  When `S` is given, no new spectrogram is computed, but `n_fft` is inferred from its shape:
https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/d9b72af964820fc796425c55d3dccd7f6b908bf9/librosa/core/spectrum.py#L2505-L2507

The problem here has been noted elsewhere, notably #978 , where we're implicitly assuming an even frame length.  Most of the time this doesn't matter, except when it does. :upside_down_face: 

In general, we can't accurately infer `n_fft` since the floor operation is inherently non-invertible.  However, we could at least check if the provided `n_fft` is consistent with `S.shape`, and return it as is if so.  If it is not, a warning should be raised.  This way, a user can at least override the incorrect inference with an explicit value and get coherent results.

**Proposed fix**
Replace https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/d9b72af964820fc796425c55d3dccd7f6b908bf9/librosa/core/spectrum.py#L2507 by:

```python
if n_fft // 2 + 1 != S.shape[-2]:  # frequency axis is -2, not 0, to support multichannel inputs
   warnings.warn('Uhoh...')
```


**Software versions***

All versions up through 0.8.1.

title: Harmonic interpolation can produce nans

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: API change
labels.description: Does this change the behavior of existing API?

body:
**Describe the bug**

This issue popped up during #1351.

Our harmonic interpolation function uses `scipy.interpolate.interp1d` under the hood, and then evaluates the interpolator at different points to produce the harmonic spectrogram planes.  By default, we use `kind='linear'`, and this works fine when the center frequencies are all unique (eg, `fft_frequencies`) so that the interpolation is well defined.

However, when using a frequency-reassigned spectrum, we may not have unique frequency values at adjacent bins, which produces an ill-defined interpolation and the following warnings:
```
/home/bmcfee/miniconda/envs/py39/lib/python3.9/site-packages/scipy/interpolate/interpolate.py:623: RuntimeWarning: divide by zero encountered in true_divide
  slope = (y_hi - y_lo) / (x_hi - x_lo)[:, None]
/home/bmcfee/miniconda/envs/py39/lib/python3.9/site-packages/scipy/interpolate/interpolate.py:626: RuntimeWarning: invalid value encountered in multiply
  y_new = slope*(x_new - x_lo)[:, None] + y_lo
```


**To Reproduce**
```
import librosa

y, sr = librosa.load(librosa.ex('trumpet'))
freqs, times, mags = librosa.reassigned_spectrogram(y, sr=sr, fill_nan=True)

mags_h = librosa.interp_harmonics(mags, freqs, h_range=[1,2,3])

# The following assertion should pass
assert np.all(np.isfinite(mags_h))
```

This is caused by a repeated frequency value, which we can detect by differencing along the frequency axis:
```python
>>> np.diff(freqs, axis=0)
Out[17]: 
array([[ 3.62758875,  4.69766474,  0.        , ..., 10.76660156,
        10.76660156, 10.76660156],
...
```

**Expected behavior**
All interpolated magnitudes should be finite.

**Proposed solution**
This behavior vanishes if we switch to a spline interpolator, eg, `kind='slinear'`.

I propose that we switch the default interpolation mode to `slinear` in 0.9, and add a note to docstring for `interp_harmonics` to discourage people from using `linear` if frequencies are not guaranteed to be unique.

Alternatively, we could check for uniqueness of frequencies at runtime, but this seems A) a bit out of scope (it should be the interpolator's job), and B) subject to numerical precision issues.  The spline interpolation modes work well in this regime, so we may as well encourage their use.

**Software versions***
Affects all versions up through 0.8.1.

title: Chromagrams: base_c = True not working if n_chroma is other than 12

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: good for beginners
labels.description: Are you new here?  These issues are for you!

body:
**Describe the bug**
When getting a chromagram of a signal with `n_chroma` other than 12 (for example, with `n_chroma = 120` to get a "micro-tonal" chromagram, so 10 bins for each of the 12 notes in an octave instead of default 1), passing `base_c = True` to it does not produce a chroma based at C, as it should. 

**To reproduce**
Here I generate 2 tones – C4 (261.63 Hz) and A4 (440 Hz) and build chromas with `n_chroma = 120` and `base_c = True`:

```
import librosa
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

from librosa.display import specshow

sr = 22050

# C4 is 261.63 Hz, A4 is 440 Hz
tone_C4 = librosa.tone(frequency=261.63, sr=sr, duration=1)
tone_A4 = librosa.tone(frequency=440, sr=sr, duration=1)

chroma_C4 = librosa.feature.chroma_stft(y=tone_C4, sr=sr, n_chroma=120, base_c = True)
chroma_A4 = librosa.feature.chroma_stft(y=tone_A4, sr=sr, n_chroma=120, base_c = True)

fig, ax = plt.subplots(1,2)

specshow(chroma_C4, y_axis=None, x_axis=None, ax=ax[0])
ax[0].set_title('C4')

specshow(chroma_A4, y_axis=None, x_axis=None, ax=ax[1])
ax[1].set_title('A4')

plt.show()
```
![bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32070551/111872125-c5b8e900-899e-11eb-9d8f-dbd64696f0bb.png)

**Expected behaviour**
The 0-th row of chroma `chroma[0,:]` should correspond to pitch class of C (that is, notes with main frequencies being twice-multiples of some C) – but it rather corresponds to something close to A, if `n_chroma` is big (as it is in the above example).
For the image below, I did `np.roll(chroma, -27, axis = 0)` (it is already rolled by -3, so -27-3 makes the needed -30):
![solved](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32070551/111872599-e97c2f00-899e-11eb-8017-3f9b0e11a9fb.png)

**Solution**
The issue is that `librosa.feature.chroma_stft` (and any other chroma-feature) passes `base_c` and `n_chroma` arguments to `librosa.filters.chroma` which builds the chroma-filterbank (`chroma_stft` then just multiplies the spectrogram by it). And in `librosa.filters.chroma`, `n_chroma` is not taken into account if `base_c = True`, it just does:
```
wts = np.roll(wts, -3, axis=0)
```
That is ok if `n_chroma=12`, since the spectrogram is built starting from A-s, and there are 3 semitones from C to A, so you just do an `np.roll` by -3 to start with C rather than A. But with `n_chroma != 12`, I suspect, you should rather do something like
```
wts = np.roll(wts, -3*(n_chroma//12), axis=0)
```

**Code patch**
In `librosa.filters`

```
@cache(level=10)
def chroma(sr, n_fft, n_chroma=12, A440=440.0, ctroct=5.0,
           octwidth=2, norm=2, base_c=True):
    
    wts = np.zeros((n_chroma, n_fft))

    # Get the FFT bins, not counting the DC component
    frequencies = np.linspace(0, sr, n_fft, endpoint=False)[1:]

    frqbins = n_chroma * hz_to_octs(frequencies, A440)

    # make up a value for the 0 Hz bin = 1.5 octaves below bin 1
    # (so chroma is 50% rotated from bin 1, and bin width is broad)
    frqbins = np.concatenate(([frqbins[0] - 1.5 * n_chroma], frqbins))

    binwidthbins = np.concatenate((np.maximum(frqbins[1:] - frqbins[:-1],
                                              1.0), [1]))

    D = np.subtract.outer(frqbins, np.arange(0, n_chroma, dtype='d')).T

    n_chroma2 = np.round(float(n_chroma) / 2)

    # Project into range -n_chroma/2 .. n_chroma/2
    # add on fixed offset of 10*n_chroma to ensure all values passed to
    # rem are positive
    D = np.remainder(D + n_chroma2 + 10*n_chroma, n_chroma) - n_chroma2

    # Gaussian bumps - 2*D to make them narrower
    wts = np.exp(-0.5 * (2*D / np.tile(binwidthbins, (n_chroma, 1)))**2)

    # normalize each column
    wts = util.normalize(wts, norm=norm, axis=0)

    # Maybe apply scaling for fft bins
    if octwidth is not None:
        wts *= np.tile(
            np.exp(-0.5 * (((frqbins/n_chroma - ctroct)/octwidth)**2)),
            (n_chroma, 1))

    if base_c:
        wts = np.roll(wts, -3, axis=0)

    # remove aliasing columns, copy to ensure row-contiguity
    return np.ascontiguousarray(wts[:, :int(1 + n_fft/2)])
```

**Software versions***
```
Python 3.7.3
librosa 0.8.0
numpy 1.16.3
matplotlib 3.1.0
```

title: Add a normalize flag for librosa.onset.onset_detect

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Does this improve existing functionality?

labels.name: functionality
labels.description: Does this add new functionality?

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
`librosa.onset.onset_detect` normalizes the onset_envelope by default, which means that I get different results based on how much of a clip I use. Although I understand the purpose of this, in my case I don't want this normalized.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Add a flag, e.g. `normalize` to `librosa.onset.onset_detect`, defaulting to True for backwards compatability.

```
def onset_detect(y=None, sr=22050, onset_envelope=None, hop_length=512,
                 backtrack=False, energy=None,
                 units='frames', normalize=True, **kwargs):
    # First, get the frame->beat strength profile if we don't already have one
    if onset_envelope is None:
        if y is None:
            raise ParameterError('y or onset_envelope must be provided')

        onset_envelope = onset_strength(y=y, sr=sr, hop_length=hop_length)

    # Shift onset envelope up to be non-negative
    # (a common normalization step to make the threshold more consistent)
    onset_envelope -= onset_envelope.min()

    # Do we have any onsets to grab?
    if not onset_envelope.any():
        return np.array([], dtype=np.int)

    # Add check for normalize flag
    if normalize:
        # Normalize onset strength function to [0, 1] range
        onset_envelope /= onset_envelope.max()

    ...

    return onsets
```

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I currently reimplement `onset_detect` without the normalize step.

**Additional context**
I'd be happy to make a PR for this.

title: Maybe I found and fix a bug in librosa.display

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
Hi, Librosa Team:
As I mentioned in Issue  #1261 and Issue  #1243, the fig with a `cqt_note` y-axis didn't behave as I expect. So I read the code and matplotlib's document. Then I found some mistakes. After that, I use some code to correct them:

1. In `/librosa/display.py#L216` (the formatter of y-axis), the contributor wrote:https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/a53fa56bdb6695a994008d5b6ccd0100870a6036/librosa/display.py#L216, with a `int(x)` , in fact, this made the ticks away from where they should stay. My suggest is to delete the `int()` and use the float data instead.

2. In `/librosa/display.py#L1064`(the locator of y-axis), the contributor wrote:https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/a53fa56bdb6695a994008d5b6ccd0100870a6036/librosa/display.py#L1064, In my opinion, this doesn't make sense. I think we should use `FixedLocator(librosa.cqt_frequencies(85, fmin=librosa.note_to_hz('C1')))` instead, because `cqt_frequencies` is designed to compute the center frequencies of Constant-Q bins. See: https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/a53fa56bdb6695a994008d5b6ccd0100870a6036/librosa/core/convert.py#L1105-L1140


My full code:
```python
def set_axis(ax) -> None:
    """call AFTER you draw!!
    =========================
    Args:
        ax : Axes
    Returns:
        None
    """
    from matplotlib.ticker import LogLocator, FixedLocator
    from matplotlib.ticker import FuncFormatter

    def _major_fomatter(x, pos):
        """Fomatter for major ticks"""
        # print('MAJOR  ' + str(x) + '  ' + str(librosa.hz_to_note(x, octave=True, cents=True)))
        if x <= 0:
            return ""
        else:
            return librosa.hz_to_note(x, octave=True, cents=True)  # necessary for cents
            # return librosa.hz_to_note(x, octave=True, cents=False)

    def _minor_fomatter(x, pos):
        """Fomatter for minor ticks"""
        # print('MINOR  ' + str(x) + '  ' + str(librosa.hz_to_note(x, octave=True, cents=True)))
        if x <= 0:
            return ""
        vmin, vmax = ax.yaxis.get_view_interval()
        if vmax > 4 * max(1, vmin):
            return ""
        # return librosa.hz_to_note(x, octave=True, cents=True)  # debug
        return librosa.hz_to_note(x, octave=True, cents=False)
    """=Set Locator & Fomatter="""
    # log_C1 = np.log2(librosa.note_to_hz("C1"));
    # offset = 2.0 ** (log_C1 - np.floor(log_C1))
    offset = librosa.note_to_hz("C1") / 32
    ax.yaxis.set_major_locator(LogLocator(base=2.0, subs=(offset,)))
    ax.yaxis.set_minor_locator(
        FixedLocator(librosa.cqt_frequencies(
            85, fmin=librosa.note_to_hz('C1')))
    )
    ax.yaxis.set_major_formatter(_major_fomatter)
    ax.yaxis.set_minor_formatter(_minor_fomatter)
    return None
```

I didn't read the source code so carefully, and that's why I don't want to put my code into the librosa package by a PR.
If anyone have a good idea, feel free to make your own PR, just remember @unbadfish in you PR.

@bmcfee , I think I fix the "bug" I found

title: specshow has incorrect mel axis for non-default sr

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
**Describe the bug**
When you call `librosa.display.specshow(..., y_axis='mel', sr=sr)` where `sr != 22050` and you leave `fmax=None`, the mel to Hz conversion is incorrect. 

Basically, in `__coord_mel_hz`, if `fmax is None`, it assumes that `fmax = 22050 / 2`, but it really should be `sr / 2`

Looping in @cmydlarz since he pointed it out to me.

(At first I thought #1235 was discussing this as well, but on closer read it's not the same issue.)

**To Reproduce**

```python
import librosa
import librosa.display
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

fname = librosa.util.example('brahms')
srs = 44100, 16000, 8000

plt.figure(figsize=(15, 5))
for i, sr in enumerate(srs, 1):
    y, sr = librosa.load(fname, sr=sr)
    
    S = librosa.feature.melspectrogram(y, sr=sr)

    plt.subplot(1, len(srs), i)
    librosa.display.specshow(
        librosa.power_to_db(S), 
        y_axis='mel', x_axis='time', 
        cmap='magma', sr=sr)
    plt.title(f'sr={sr}')
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6741720/93398497-b15a2f00-f849-11ea-843b-c103e799b080.png)


**Expected behavior**
(see y ticks vs title)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6741720/93398542-c20aa500-f849-11ea-9f33-ae263e672cf0.png)


**Solution**
Temporary workaround
```python
librosa.display.specshow(..., y_axis='mel', sr=sr, fmax=sr/2.)
```
Code patch
```python
def __coord_mel_hz(n, fmin=0, fmax=None, sr=22050, **_kwargs):
    '''Get the frequencies for Mel bins'''

    if fmin is None:
        fmin = 0
    if fmax is None:
        fmax = sr / 2.

    basis = librosa.mel_frequencies(n, fmin=fmin, fmax=fmax)
    basis[1:] -= 0.5 * np.diff(basis)
    basis = np.append(np.maximum(0, basis), [fmax])
    return basis
librosa.display.__coord_mel_hz = __coord_mel_hz
```

title: Fix padding for IIRT

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
Again a small fix for IIRT. In the current version, the padding (for `center=True`) is not done properly. This PR fixes this issue.

The following code example illustrates the issue by comparing the STFT and IIRT output for increasing window sizes. For STFT, the number of frames is always the same. Without this PR, the number of frames varies for IIRT.

```python
import librosa

x, Fs = librosa.load(librosa.util.example_audio_file(), duration=1.0)
H = 512

for i in range(1, 7):
    N = i * H
    X_stft = librosa.stft(x, n_fft=N, hop_length=H, win_length=N, center=True)
    X_iirt = librosa.iirt(x, sr=Fs, hop_length=H, win_length=N, center=True)
    
    print(f'Num frames for STFT: {X_stft.shape[1]}; Num frames for STFT: {X_iirt.shape[1]}')
```

Output before this PR:
```
Num frames for STFT: 44; Num frames for STFT: 45
Num frames for STFT: 44; Num frames for STFT: 44
Num frames for STFT: 44; Num frames for STFT: 43
Num frames for STFT: 44; Num frames for STFT: 42
Num frames for STFT: 44; Num frames for STFT: 41
Num frames for STFT: 44; Num frames for STFT: 40
```

Output with this PR:
```
Num frames for STFT: 44; Num frames for STFT: 44
Num frames for STFT: 44; Num frames for STFT: 44
Num frames for STFT: 44; Num frames for STFT: 44
Num frames for STFT: 44; Num frames for STFT: 44
Num frames for STFT: 44; Num frames for STFT: 44
Num frames for STFT: 44; Num frames for STFT: 44
```

title: Fix hopsize issue for iirt

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
We found a severe bug in the iirt function.

Three different sample rates are used to compute the bands for iirt. For each sample rate, a distinct hop size is used to compute the short-time mean-square power (STMSP). Without this bug fix, the hop sizes were rounded and then applied, which is problematic. The rounding error leads to increasing shifts that are different for each of the three sample rates. As a consequence, for longer waveforms, the three frequency bands are out of sync. We solved this by computing the start indices for the windows before rounding.

The following code example illustrates the issue:

    import numpy as np
    import librosa
    from matplotlib import pyplot as plt

    Fs = 22050
    x = librosa.clicks([10, 50, 90, 130, 170], sr=Fs, length=180*Fs)
    X = librosa.iirt(x)

    plt.figure(figsize=(10, 4))
    plt.imshow(np.log(X + 1e-7), aspect='auto', origin='lower', cmap='gray_r', extent=[0, 180, 24, 108])
    plt.colorbar()
    plt.xlabel('Time (seconds)')
    plt.ylabel('Pitch')

The result without the bug fix:
![old](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5499717/84139996-2f3fba80-aa51-11ea-9dd6-68a97f68c89a.png)


The result with the bug fix:
![new](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5499717/84140010-34046e80-aa51-11ea-8b40-6561e897da46.png)

Thanks to @ahnonay, who found the issue! Also, ping to @stefan-balke who might be interested.

title: n_columns goes to zero for large window sizes of stft

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
#### Description
spotted by @fzalkow in PR #1094

The STFT fails when using large window sizes. This is due to the computation of `n_columns`, which can be zero. `n_columns` is used as third argument for `range`, which must not be zero. To be honest, I don't fully get the idea of the computation of `n_columns`. I just added a quick fix to enforce that `n_columns` is at least one.


#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
```python
import numpy as np 
import librosa

x = np.empty(1000000)

for exponent in range(12, 17):
    N = 2 ** exponent
    H = N // 2
    print(N, H)
    X = librosa.stft(x, n_fft=N, hop_length=H, win_length=N)
```


#### Expected Results
Pass

#### Actual Results
`ValueError: range() arg 3 must not be zero`

#### Versions
librosa 0.7.2

title: STFT fails for large window sizes

The STFT fails when using large window sizes. This is due to the computation of `n_columns`, which can be zero. `n_columns` is used as third argument for `range`, which must not be zero. The following code example illustrates the issue:

import numpy as np 
import librosa

x = np.empty(1000000)

for exponent in range(12, 17):
    N = 2 ** exponent
    H = N // 2
    print(N, H)

title: Fix librosa.feature.rms #1040

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look at
the contribution guidelines: https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-to-contribute
-->
#### Reference Issue
<!-- Example: Fixes #123 -->
Fixes #1040

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
I changed the calculation algorithm of `librosa.feature.rms` when giving `S` (not `y`).
In order to satisfy Parseval's equation, the negative frequency bins' power is correctly handled.
Since the calculation formula is slightly different when `n_fft` is odd and even, the new argument `odd_n_fft` is added.
This argument specifies whether or not the `n_fft` used when computing `S` is odd.
(`odd_n_fft` does nothing when `y` is given.)

Here is a sample snippet.
```python
import librosa

frame_length_even = 2048
frame_length_odd = 2049
hop_length = 512
center = True

# make a wave and its spectrogram 
y = np.random.rand(3000)  # wave 
S_even = librosa.magphase(librosa.stft(y,  # spectrogram 
        n_fft=frame_length_even, 
        hop_length=hop_length, 
        window=np.ones))[0]
S_odd = librosa.magphase(librosa.stft(y,  # spectrogram 
        n_fft=frame_length_odd, 
        hop_length=hop_length, 
        window=np.ones))[0] 

# calculate RMS 
rms_even_y = librosa.feature.rms(y=y, frame_length=frame_length_even, hop_length=hop_length, center=center)
rms_even_S = librosa.feature.rms(S=S_even, center=center)
rms_odd_y = librosa.feature.rms(y=y, frame_length=frame_length_odd, hop_length=hop_length, center=center)
rms_odd_S = librosa.feature.rms(S=S_odd, center=center, odd_n_fft=True)
rms_odd_S_mistake = librosa.feature.rms(S=S_odd, center=center)  # mistake
print(rms_even_y, ': rms_even_y')  
print(rms_even_S, ': rms_even_S')  
print(rms_odd_y, ': rms_odd_y')  
print(rms_odd_S, ': rms_odd_S') 
print(rms_odd_S_mistake, ': rms_odd_S_mistake')
```

Output:
```
[[0.56467811 0.56795336 0.57112578 0.57611183 0.57552133 0.57208155]] : rms_even_y
[[0.5646781  0.56795336 0.57112576 0.57611182 0.57552133 0.57208155]] : rms_even_S
[[0.56471934 0.56805793 0.57113983 0.57632674 0.57539677 0.572001  ]] : rms_odd_y
[[0.56471935 0.56805794 0.57113982 0.57632676 0.57539679 0.57200101]] : rms_odd_S
[[0.56488239 0.56820956 0.57133744 0.57660026 0.57567047 0.5722761 ]] : rms_odd_S_mistake
```

#### Any other comments?
I changed the test code `test_rms()` in `test_features.py`.

title: librosa.feature.rms inconsistency - y vs S

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
<!--
If your issue is a usage question, submit it our Google Group instead: 
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/librosa
-->

<!-- Instructions For Filing a Bug: https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#filing-bugs -->

#### Description
<!-- Example: Error when computing spectral_contrast on a single frame-->
When calling `librosa.feature.rms`, the result using a wave `y` and the result using the spectrogram `S` are different.  
This is because the algorithm is not correctly implemented to satisfy the Parseval's equation.  

![texclip20191213224740](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15100931/70804763-a1b14400-1dfa-11ea-90f6-4a4051d84a13.png)

Specifically, the direct current bin `S[0]` (and only if `n_fft` is odd, the sr/2 bin `S[-1]`) has twice as much influence as the other bins.

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
<!--
Example:
```
import librosa

# Generate one frame of random STFT-like energy
S = np.random.randn(1025, 1)**2

contrast = librosa.feature.spectral_contrast(S=S)
```
If the code is too long, feel free to put it in a public gist and link
it in the issue: https://gist.github.com
-->
```python
import numpy as np
import librosa

# set paramters
np.random.seed(0)
frame_length = 2048
hop_length = 512
center = True

# make a wave and its spectrogram
y = np.random.rand(3000)  # wave, DC component is about 0.5 because the range of np.random.rand is [0, 1)
S = librosa.magphase(librosa.stft(y,  # spectrogram
        n_fft=frame_length,
        hop_length=hop_length,
        window=np.ones,
        center=center))[0]

# calculate RMS
rms1 = librosa.feature.rms(y=y, frame_length=frame_length, hop_length=hop_length, center=center)
rms2 = librosa.feature.rms(S=S, frame_length=frame_length, hop_length=hop_length, center=center)
print(rms1)
print(rms2)
print(np.allclose(rms1, rms2))
```

#### Expected Results
<!-- Example: contrast should have shape (1, 1)-->
`rms1` and `rms2` are almost the same.

#### Actual Results
<!-- Please paste or specifically describe the actual output or traceback. -->
```
[[0.57401353 0.58105711 0.58252662 0.58571533 0.58668334 0.58252178]]
[[0.75760764 0.76713306 0.76892614 0.7742523  0.77579546 0.77086043]]
False
```

title: "File contains data in an unknown format." when loading mp3 given a pathlib.Path

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
#### Description
When using librosa.load to load a mp3 file given a pathlib.Path, you'll get a "File contains data in an unknown format" error.  I tried installing ffmpeg over and over again before I realized it's definitely a bug within librosa.load in a specific constellation. It took some time before I realized how to reproduce that, but it's actually stupidly simple:

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
```
import librosa
from pathlib import Path

# works
aaa = librosa.load('./test1_22050.mp3')
aaa = librosa.load('./test1_22050.wav')
aaa = librosa.load(Path('./test1_22050.wav'))

# doesn't work
aaa = librosa.load(Path('./test1_22050.mp3'))
```

Since a "normal" load (without pathlib.Path) falls back to audioread instead of PySoundFile according to the usual warning in case of mp3 files, I strongly suspect that this fallback just somehow fails when using pathlib.
Temporary workaround for users: just do
```
aaa = librosa.load(str(Path('./test1_22050.mp3')))

if your code utilizes pathlib.

title: Scaling issue in RMS computation

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
#### Description
Scaling issue in RMS computation `librosa.feature.rms` when the input is the magnitude spectrogram (specifying `S`)

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce

Example:
```
import librosa
fs = 48000
block_size = fs // 4
hop_size = fs // 8
x = np.linspace(start=0, stop=10 * fs, num=10 * fs)
y = np.sin(2.0 * np.pi * 200.0 * x / fs)

# compute RMS from spectrogram
S, _ = librosa.magphase(librosa.stft(y, n_fft=block_size, hop_length=hop_size, center=True, window=np.ones))
rms_spec = librosa.feature.rms(S=S)   # rms value  is approx. 77.45

# compute RMS from samples
rms_samp = librosa.feature.rms(
    y, 
    frame_length=block_size, 
    hop_length=hop_size, 
    center=True
)  # rms value is approx. 0.707 which is expected (rms for sine wave is 1/sqrt(2))
```

#### Expected Results
The RMS of a unit sine wave should ideally be `1/sqrt(2) = 0.707`. 

#### Actual Results
`rms_time` gives the correct results whereas `rms_spec` seems to scaled by a factor of `sqrt(N)` where `N` is the fft-length. I use a rectangular window to ensure this is not due to windowing effects. 

#### Versions

Please run the following snippet and paste the output below.

title: Resample does not preserve byte ordering

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
#### Description

In experimenting with prototypes for #916 / #944 , I discovered that our resample wrapper may change the contiguity properties of data being converted.  This is due to a call to `ascontiguousarray` at the end of the function, which I think can be removed wholesale.

This doesn't entirely solve the problem though, because `resampy` has the same issue (for a different reason), as noted here https://github.com/bmcfee/resampy/issues/68

A proper fix for this problem will require fixing resampy, bumping the minimum version requirement in librosa, and dropping the call to `ascontiguousarray`.

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce

Example:
```python
>>> import librosa
>>> y, sr = librosa.load(librosa.util.example_audio_file(), mono=False, sr=None)
>>> y.flags
  C_CONTIGUOUS : False
  F_CONTIGUOUS : True
  OWNDATA : False
  WRITEABLE : True
  ALIGNED : True
  WRITEBACKIFCOPY : False
  UPDATEIFCOPY : False
>>> y2 = librosa.resample(y, sr, sr//2)
>>> y2.flags
  C_CONTIGUOUS : True
  F_CONTIGUOUS : False
  OWNDATA : True
  WRITEABLE : True
  ALIGNED : True
  WRITEBACKIFCOPY : False
  UPDATEIFCOPY : False
```

#### Expected Results
`y2` should have `F_CONTIGUOUS: True` 

#### Actual Results
`y2` is `C_CONTIGUOUS`

#### Versions

librosa 0.7.1dev (and 0.7.0), resampy 0.2.1.

title: File objects work with librosa.load but not librosa.stream

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: IO
labels.description: Issues relating to reading and writing (audio) data

body:
#### Description
Loading a WAV file via tf.gfile.GFile works with `librosa.load` but not `librosa.stream`. Interestingly the same error appears regardless of if it is a bucket path or a local path.

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
```py
import librosa as lr
import tensorflow as tf

path = 'gs://my-bucket/example.wav'

# Loading the entire file works as expected.
with tf.gfile.GFile(path, 'rb') as f:
    lr.load(f, 48000)

# The streaming method crashes.
with tf.gfile.GFile(path, 'rb') as f:
    assert f.seekable() is True
    for waveforms in lr.stream(f, 128, 1024, 512):
        print(waveforms.shape)
```
#### Expected Results
No errors.

#### Actual Results
> RuntimeError: Error opening : File contains data in an unknown format.

#### Versions

#### Description
Originally described by @fzalkow in #920. Copy-pasting his issue report below so that we can tack it to v0.7.1 release notes.

> For non-subsequence dynamic time warping, the boundary condition is not always satisfied. 
This is because the backtracking loop currently stops when the beginning of the first sequence is reached. That makes sense for subsequence DTW, but not for usual DTW.

import numpy as np
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
import librosa

x = np.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])

D, wp = librosa.sequence.dtw(x, y)

plt.imshow(D, aspect='auto', cmap='gray_r', origin='lower')
plt.plot(wp[:, 1], wp[:, 0], 'ro-')
```

title: CQT tuning correction, tuning standardization, deprecate A440=

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Does this improve existing functionality?

labels.name: functionality
labels.description: Does this add new functionality?

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: Issues relating to docstrings, examples, and documentation build

labels.name: API change
labels.description: Does this change the behavior of existing API?

body:
#### Reference Issue
Fixes #925 


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.

This PR addresses the following issues:

- [x] redundant tuning estimation in CQT
- [x] incorrect bin resolution of CQT tuning estimation
- [x] deprecation of `tuning=` parameter in CQT basis constructors
- [x] standardize `tuning=` parameter to be in "fractions of a bin" rather than "cents" across the library
- [x] deprecate `A440=` parameters in favor of `tuning=` parameters across the library.

#### Any other comments?

As mentioned in the discussion of #925, the approach to tuning correction going forward is to simplify the CQT basis constructors to not support tuning.  Rather, it is the job of the caller (ie, `librosa.cqt`) to adjust the `fmin` parameter as a function of tuning prior to requesting the basis.  This simplifies all of the downstream logic, and clarifies exactly the interpretation of `fmin` when tuning is non-zero.

A couple of quirks that popped up in implementing this:

- Should we support `tuning=` in the display module, ie in specshow?  If we don't, then the bin centers for `cqt_hz` decoration will be incorrect.  However, the user may not have the tuning value on-hand if it's automatically calculated and not returned.

- Can we find a more accurate reference for `filters.constant_q`?  The function has generalized substantially from its first implementation, and I don't think the ref we have now is appropriate.

I'll signal for a CR once the last two bullet points are done.

title: inconsistent/double calculation of tuning in cqt

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: Issues relating to docstrings, examples, and documentation build

labels.name: API change
labels.description: Does this change the behavior of existing API?

body:
#### Description
When the `tuning` argument of `librosa.cqt()` is `None`, it estimates tuning by [calling `estimate_tuning()`](https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/0.7.0/librosa/core/constantq.py#L174-L175) to find the tuning and [calls `cqt_frequencies()`](https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/0.7.0/librosa/core/constantq.py#L178-L179).

1. The call to `estimate_tuning()` uses its default argument `bins_per_octave=12` always, but the call to `cqt_frequencies()` uses the `bins_per_octave` argument given to `cqt()`. This makes [the frequency correction term](https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/0.7.0/librosa/core/time_frequency.py#L957) different from the intended tuning, by a factor of `12 / bins_per_octave`.

2. Furthermore, `cqt()` calls `__cqt_filter_fft` with `fmin_t` in which the [tuning correction is already applied](https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/0.7.0/librosa/core/constantq.py#L178-L181), and in `constant_q` [the correction is applied once again](https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/0.7.0/librosa/filters.py#L512-L513). So the tuning correction is twice larger than it should be.

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce

This example uses a sound that is 42 cents above the standard A440 tuning. `estimate_tuning` returns 0.43 (which is close enough).

```
import numpy as np
import librosa

sr = 22050
fmin = librosa.note_to_hz('Ab4')
freq = librosa.note_to_hz('A4') * 2 ** (42 / 1200)  # 42 cent above A440
t = np.linspace(0, 1, sr, endpoint=False)
y = np.sin(2 * np.pi * freq * t)
print(np.abs(librosa.cqt(y, sr, fmin=fmin, n_bins=7, bins_per_octave=36, tuning=None))[:, 10])
```

#### Expected Results
If the tuning is correctly identified, the CQT spectrum would be symmetric around the peak.

#### Actual Results
The spectrum is not symmetric and the peak lies somewhere between the 4th and 5th bin.

`[ 0.05483014  0.67865918  5.63108114 22.61531804 19.71375346  3.43137636
  0.56649648]`

#### Workaround

To apply a certain `tuning` value, I can instead give `(tuning / 2) * (bins_per_octave / 12)`, dividing by 2 to compensate for the double calculation and multiplying by `bins_per_octave / 12` to compensate for the incorrect `estimate_tuning()` call.

So if I run the following instead:

`print(np.abs(librosa.cqt(y, sr, fmin=fmin, n_bins=7, bins_per_octave=36, tuning=0.63))[:, 10])`

I get a symmetric spectrum:

`[ 0.07743703  0.08895902 12.56089353 24.92553951 12.64337768  0.22712318
  0.11059439]`

#### Versions

```
Linux-4.15.0-54-generic-x86_64-with-debian-buster-sid
Python 3.7.3 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Jul  1 2019, 21:52:21) 
[GCC 7.3.0]
NumPy 1.16.4
SciPy 1.3.0
librosa 0.7.0
```

I think it'd be better if tuning is always defined in terms of 'fractions of a bin' and avoid using the term 'cents' altogether, as it's confusing with the music theory term (a 100th of a semitone)

<!-- Thanks for contributing! -->

title: Window derivative in ifgram

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Does this improve existing functionality?

body:
#### Description
<!-- Example: Error when computing spectral_contrast on a single frame-->
The window derivative `d_window` that is calculated in `ifgram()` is appropriate for the default Hann window, but not for other analysis windows.

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce

https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/65cbc8291cc265b93236b871727d2a4ec9cf3d06/librosa/core/spectrum.py#L469-L472

These lines in `librosa.core.ifgram()` create an array with the window derivative. They don't use the `window` argument to `ifgram()` to calculate the derivative, but they do produce the (negative) window derivative when the default Hann window is used:

```
import numpy as np

n_fft = 1024

freq_angular = np.linspace(0, 2 * np.pi, n_fft, endpoint=False) 
d_window = np.sin(-freq_angular) * np.pi / n_fft

np.allclose(d_window, -np.gradient(np.hanning(n_fft)), atol=2e-5)
# True
```

But the calculation for `d_window` doesn't lead to the derivative for other windows:

```
np.allclose(d_window, -np.gradient(np.blackman(n_fft)), atol=2e-5)
# False

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

x = np.arange(n_fft)

plt.plot(x, d_window, c="black")
plt.scatter(x, -np.gradient(np.hanning(n_fft)), s=0.1, c="red")
plt.scatter(x, -np.gradient(np.blackman(n_fft)), s=0.1, c="blue")
plt.show()
```

`d_window` is used for `diff_stft` on these lines:

https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/65cbc8291cc265b93236b871727d2a4ec9cf3d06/librosa/core/spectrum.py#L479-L481

This is described in section 2 of the paper referenced in the docstring (Abe, Kobayashi, & Imai 1995), or equation 5.20 of Flandrin, Auger, & Chassande-Mottin (2002).

I might be misunderstanding, but I think that `d_window` should be using `np.gradient()` or another numerical derivative of the `window` argument. Flandrin et al. have an alternative calculation with MATLAB code for the window derivative in section 5.3.1.3 that might be better at the edges than `np.gradient()`.

#### Versions
```
Python 3.6.5
NumPy 1.14.5
SciPy 1.1.0
librosa 0.6.1
```

Abe, T., Kobayashi, T., & Imai, S. (1995). Harmonics tracking and pitch extraction based on instantaneous frequency. 1995 International Conference on Acoustics, Speech, and Signal Processing, 1, 756–759. https://doi.org/10.1109/ICASSP.1995.479804

Flandrin, P., Auger, F., & Chassande-Mottin, E. (2002). Time-Frequency reassignment: from principles to algorithms. In Applications in Time-Frequency Signal Processing (Vol. 10, pp. 179–204). CRC Press.

title: [CR wanted] ICQT rewrite

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.description: Does this improve existing functionality?

labels.name: API change
labels.description: Does this change the behavior of existing API?

body: #### Reference Issue Fixes #802 #### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes. This PR is a complete rewrite of the icqt implementation. The new implementation is much simpler, and uses `istft` to perform each octave band's inverse transform, rather than populating the waveform manually. It fixes the numerical stability issues mentioned in #802, as well as a number of other scaling issues. The `amin` parameter has been deprecated, as it is no longer necessary. A new `length=` parameter has been added for style compatibility with other inverse transforms. A warning is now issued if the analysis parameters are not sufficient for reconstruction, namely when the shortest filter length is less than the hop length (non-overlapping filters). #### Any other comments? Here are some example inputs / outputs using a triangular-windowed sine sweep from C1 to C8. All error estimates are restricted to the non-zero portion of the signal. ``` hop_length = 512 oversample = 1 filter_scale = 1 n_octaves = 7 scale=True sparsity = 1e-3 ``` ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1190540/54696297-f345d000-4b01-11e9-8504-20b0fa1e3d93.png) RMSE: 0.343, MAE: 0.194 --- ``` hop_length = 512 oversample = 5 filter_scale = 1 n_octaves = 7 scale=True sparsity = 1e-3 ``` ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1190540/54696373-11133500-4b02-11e9-9552-7370bc3b24f2.png) RMSE: 0.018, MAE: 0.011 --- ``` hop_length = 512 oversample = 9 filter_scale = 1 n_octaves = 7 scale=True sparsity = 1e-3 ``` ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1190540/54696179-bda0e700-4b01-11e9-9c98-b15bbee1a594.png) RMSE: 0.004, MAE: 0.003 --- ``` hop_length = 512 oversample = 7 filter_scale = 1 n_octaves = 9 scale=True sparsity = 1e-3 ``` ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1190540/54696477-461f8780-4b02-11e9-9d41-abf640234628.png) RMSE: 0.007, MAE: 0.005 --- ``` hop_length = 256 oversample = 5 filter_scale = 1 n_octaves = 7 scale=True sparsity = 1e-3 ``` ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1190540/54696526-60596580-4b02-11e9-9007-b0c3b74844cb.png) RMSE: 0.007, MAE: 0.011 --- All results are identical with `scale=False`. At this point, I'm happy with the implementation. Additional eyeballs for CR would be appreciated, but it's a substantial CR job due to its interdependence with the CQT implementation. I'd settle for a quick smell test, and a look over the documentation and warnings. Otherwise I can merge once it passes CI. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/librosa/librosa/852)

title: PCEN should not initialize with silence

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Does this improve existing functionality?

body:
#### Description
Adapted from https://github.com/librosa/librosa/issues/615#issuecomment-473009124, initially raised by @4p0pt0Z 

When using the current implementation of the PCEN, artifacts appear due to the filter initialization. Currently, the filter is created with
`S_smooth = scipy.signal.lfilter([b], [1, b - 1], ref, axis=axis)`

When the initial conditions for the filter are not specified, initial rest is assumed.
See documentation of `zi` at this address: https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy-1.2.1/reference/generated/scipy.signal.lfilter.html

The initialization to zero is equivalent to assuming that the signal is preceded by an infinitely long silence. This is not realistic and causes numerical artifacts in the earliest timestamps of the PCEN-gram, especially in the most active bands.

#### Expected Results vs. Actual Results

Thanks to @f0k and @bmcfee, we already have a plan for a workaround:
* expose the `zi` as a kwarg parameter in the prototype of `pcen`
* `zi` defaults to `None`, in which case it gets automatically set as in steady-state.

This is how we plan to do it: https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy-1.2.1/reference/generated/scipy.signal.lfilter_zi.html#scipy.signal.lfilter_zi

Top: current results (with zero initialization of `zi`). Bottom: expected results (with: steady-state initialization of `zi`).

![54450887-dbe49c80-4727-11e9-9777-e39f1e059aa8 (1)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3943142/54458075-6eda0280-4739-11e9-8cba-9b681b196634.png)


#### Versions
```
librosa 0.6.3
scipy 1.2.1
```

title: Maybe a better Implementation of Method "pitch_tuning" in librosa/core/pitch.py

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: good for beginners
labels.description: Are you new here?  These issues are for you!

body:
<!--
If your issue is a usage question, submit it our Google Group instead: 
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/librosa
-->

<!-- Instructions For Filing a Bug: https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#filing-bugs -->

#### Description
<!-- Example: Error when computing spectral_contrast on a single frame-->

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
<!--
Example:
```
import librosa

# Generate one frame of random STFT-like energy
S = np.random.randn(1025, 1)**2

contrast = librosa.feature.spectral_contrast(S=S)
```
If the code is too long, feel free to put it in a public gist and link
it in the issue: https://gist.github.com
-->

#### Expected Results
<!-- Example: contrast should have shape (1, 1)-->

#### Actual Results
<!-- Please paste or specifically describe the actual output or traceback. -->

#### Versions
<!--
Please run the following snippet and paste the output below.
import platform; print(platform.platform())
import sys; print("Python", sys.version)
import numpy; print("NumPy", numpy.__version__)
import scipy; print("SciPy", scipy.__version__)
import librosa; print("librosa", librosa.__version__)
-->


<!-- Thanks for contributing! -->


librosa ›
--
 
Maybe a better Implementation of Method "pitch_tuning" in librosa/core/pitch.py

In librosa/core/pitch.py, line 157, "bins = np.linspace(-0.5, 0.5, int(np.ceil(1./resolution)), endpoint=False)"  is written. However, I reckon that it is better to be written like this: "bins = np.linspace(-0.5, 0.5, int(np.ceil(1./resolution))+1)" .

Here is my reason:


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37358510/50464260-e023d800-09ca-11e9-801d-6e68f20e33dc.png)



When you use **bins1** as an input of **np.histogram()**, it has actually 9 bins: [-0.5, -.0.4), ... [0.2, 0.3), [0.3, 0.4]. So any elements > 0.4 in **residuals** will not be counted(see **counts1**). Even if you set the **resolution** as 0.01, any elements > 0.49 in **residuals** will not be counted, which means the range of the **pitch_tuning()**'s return is [-0.5, 0.49], instead of [-0.5, 0.5).

However, look at **bins2** and **counts2**. When put **bins2** in **np.histogram()**, it has actually 10 bins: [-0.5, -.0.4), ... [0.3, 0.4), [0.4, 0.5], and all elements in **residuals** will be counted(because all elements in residuals is between[-0.5, 0.5) ). Now the range of the **pitch_tuning()**'s return is  [-0.5, 0.5), it is more in accordance with the method's description.

title: Rewrite of match_intervals

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Does this improve existing functionality?

labels.name: functionality
labels.description: Does this add new functionality?

body: #### Reference Issue Implements #706 #### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes. This PR includes a rewrite of the `match_intervals` function as described in #706. This was originally intended as an acceleration enhancement, but we discovered some unspecified behavior bugs in the process, and it is now more of a bug-fix PR. The behavior of `match_intervals` has changed somewhat. In the old version, it would find the interval with maximum intersection, and if none exists, it would match to 0 (unintended behavior). The new implementation operates in two modes, `strict=True|False`. In both cases, overlapping intervals are matched to maximize Jaccard similarity. When `strict=True`, if a query interval is disjoint from all targets, an exception is now thrown. When `strict=False`, a disjoint query interval will instead match to the target with boundary closest to the query -- this can be interpreted as tie-breaking when no intersection exists. `strict=True` is the default. #### Any other comments? The new implementation is a bit slower than the old implementation for common input sizes. However, it is still acceptably fast, and now has well-specified behavior for all inputs. Because there is now substantial helper code for the matching functions (intervals and events), they have been broken out of `util.utils` and placed in a separate submodule `util.matching`. This should not have any user-facing effect. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/librosa/librosa/714)

title: General match_intervals improvements

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Does this improve existing functionality?

labels.name: functionality
labels.description: Does this add new functionality?

body:
#### Description
In auditing `match_intervals` in preparation for numbafication #157, I noticed a couple of undocumented / undefined behaviors that should be made explicit.  I'm tagging these as "bug" because they are definitely not intended behavior, and could silently cause some strange behaviors down the road.

1. What should happen when a query interval has no overlap with any of the targets?  The current logic for this is [here](https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/master/librosa/util/utils.py#L837), which would amount to argmax over an all zeros vector.  `np.argmax` breaks ties in favor of the first maximal element, which in this case, would be 0 (the first target interval).  This seems bad and wrong here.

  Some suggested alternative behaviors:

  - Use a null value.  `None` seems reasonable, but it would require returning a list of ints instead of a `ndarray(dtype=int)`.  `NaN` also seems reasonable, but would require `dtype=float`, which would not work with fancy indexing.
  - Throw an exception.  At the very least, we should throw a warning when this happens.
  - Map to the "closest" non-overlapping interval [in the set sense](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distance#Distances_between_sets_and_between_a_point_and_a_set).
  - Maybe have a user-supplied option to switch between some of these modes?

2. How should we break ties?  The current interval scoring uses the [raw intersection](https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/master/librosa/util/utils.py#L835) between intervals, and then selects the first maximal target as the match.  This seems wrong / under-determined when there are overlapping intervals.  I think [Jaccard similarity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaccard_index) is a better selection criterion, being a proper metric and all.  This would break ties in favor of the "tightest" matching interval, which I think is sensible.

### A note on candidate filtering

@danagilliann and I worked out a slightly faster matching algorithm than what we currently have.  It's still `O(nm)` in the worst case, but in the average case, should behave more like `O(m log m + n log m)`.

Here's some simplified pseudo-code of the current method (brute-force quadratic search):
```python
output = []
for query in from_intervals:
   best_score = 0
   best_idx = 0
   for idx, candidate in enumerate(to_intervals):
      score = similarity(query, candidate)
      if score > best_score:
          best_score, best_idx = score, idx
   output.append(best_idx)
```

The acceleration idea is to quickly filter out any intervals which we know to not intersect the query.  This can be done using two sorted arrays, one for the interval starts and one for the interval ends.  Any interval with `start > query_end` will have `score==0`; likewise for any interval with `end < query_start`.  Therefore, we only need to search over intervals with `start <= query_end` and `end >= query_start`, which can each be found in time `O(log m)`.

The accelerated version of the algorithm looks as follows:
```python
output = []
start_index = np.argsort(to_intervals[:, 0])  # sort index of the interval starts
end_index = np.argsort(to_intervals[:, 1])  # sort index of the interval ends

start_sorted = to_intervals[start_index, 0]  # and sorted values of starts
end_sorted = to_intervals[end_index, 1]  # and ends

for query in from_intervals:
   # Find the intervals that start after our query ends
   after_query = np.searchsorted(start_sorted, query[1], side='right')
   # And the intervals that end after our query begins
   before_query = np.searchsorted(end_sorted, query[0], side='left')

   candidates = set(start_index[:after_query]) & set(end_index[before_query:])

   # Proceed as before
   best_score = 0
   best_idx = 0
   for idx in candidates:
      score = similarity(query, to_intervals[idx])
      if score > best_score:
          best_score, best_idx = score, idx
   output.append(best_idx)
```

The speedup here comes from the fact that we expect the `candidates` set to be small most of the time (much less than the entire `to_intervals` set).

As a side note, we can re-use these sorted arrays to quickly find the closest interval in the candidate set is empty, if that fallback mode is desired.

title: fixed #657 by reimplementing the delta function. Deprecates trim=

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Does this improve existing functionality?

labels.name: functionality
labels.description: Does this add new functionality?

labels.name: API change
labels.description: Does this change the behavior of existing API?

body: #### Reference Issue Fixes #657 #### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes. There was a bug in `feature.delta` that caused drift at higher order features. This was caused by implementing smoothed differencing by iteratively calling `scipy.signal.lfilter`. ~~~The function has been rewritten to use `scipy.ndimage.convolve1d`, so that results stay centered.~~~ This function has been rewritten to use Savitsky-Golay filtering via `scipy.signal.savgol_filter`. This gives a more general implementation of the linear smoothing previously used in `delta`, and reduces the influence of boundary effects, producing more accurate high-order difference estimates. Compared to the code example in #657: ```python In [1]: import librosa In [2]: librosa.feature.delta([-2, -1, 0, 1, 2], width=3, order=2) Out[2]: array([ 0.25, 0.5 , 0.25, 0. , -0.25]) ``` ##### Expected Results ```array([ 0.5, 0.25, 0, -0.25, -0.5])``` ##### Actual Results ```array([ 0.25, 0.5 , 0.25, 0. , -0.25])``` we now get for first-order (`mode='nearest'`): ```python array([ 0.5, 1. , 1. , 1. , 0.5]) ``` and second-order (*updated* **updated again**): ```python array([ 1.00000000e+00, 8.88178420e-16, 4.44089210e-16, 0.00000000e+00, -1.00000000e+00]) ``` With `mode='interp'`, first-order: ```python array([ 1., 1., 1., 1., 1.]) ``` and second-order: ```python array([ -2.03182142e-15, 8.88178420e-16, 4.44089210e-16, 0.00000000e+00, -5.89125247e-16]) ``` #### Any other comments? Because ~~~`convolve1d` pads implicitly~~~ `savgol_filter` pads explicitly, padding and trimming is no longer required in the `delta` API. As such, the `trim=` parameter has been deprecated, and will be removed in 0.7. Calls to `librosa.delta` now preserve shape and dtype. This is a breaking change if people relied on `trim=False` behavior previously, but I expect that this feature was not used (often) outside of our unit tests. By default, it now uses `interp` padding. As noted above, this reduces the influence of boundary effects. The old behavior can be recovered by setting `mode='nearest'`. The requirements on `width` have been tightened, and now depend on the length of the signal. The API now exposes `kwargs` parameters to `savgol_filter`, in case a user wants to change the sampling points or constant-padding behavior. The minimum scipy version has been bumped up to 0.14. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/librosa/librosa/663)

title: frame() validation is overkill / incorrectly placed

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Does this improve existing functionality?

body:
#### Description
`util.frame()` currently calls `valid_audio()` as part of its input checking.  This is probably not correct, since we may want to frame other signals (where nan/inf are okay).

Additionally, the call to `valid_audio()` happens after a check that already assumes an ndarray input.

All we really need in `frame()` is for the input to be:

- `ndarray`
- `ndim==1`
- shorter than the frame length
- contiguous
- `hop_length >= 1`

We're currently relying on `valid_audio` to check the first two properties, but these should be explicitly checked in `frame()` instead.

The call to `valid_audio` is also frequently redundant, since almost everywhere we call `frame` is after a validation check anyway.

labels.name: bug

#### Description

While discussing filters and #18 with @lostanlen today, we noticed that the CQT basis is not properly centered such that the middle sample has a peak on the real component of the filters.  This might be part of the cause of my problems with #435.

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
```python
import librosa
import librosa.display
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
%matplotlib nbagg
import numpy as np

basis, lengths = librosa.filters.constant_q(22050, filter_scale=1)

plt.figure(figsize=(10, 4))
notes = librosa.midi_to_note(np.arange(24, 24 + len(basis)))
for i, (f, n) in enumerate(zip(basis, notes[:12])):
    f_scale = librosa.util.normalize(f) / 2
    plt.plot(i + f_scale.real)
    plt.plot(i + f_scale.imag, linestyle=':')

plt.axvline(len(f_scale)//2)

plt.axis('tight')
plt.yticks(np.arange(len(notes[:12])), notes[:12])

plt.ylabel('CQ filters')
plt.title('CQ filters (one octave, time domain)')

plt.tight_layout()

```

title: fixed that some steps are ignored when len(step_size_sigma)>3 in dtw and added a parameters check

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Does this improve existing functionality?

body: Hi there, I found that some steps are ignored when `len(step_size_sigma) > 3` if `weights_add is None` or `weights_mul is None` in `librosa.dtw`. For example, ```python D, wp = librosa.dtw(X, Y, subseq = True, backtrack = True, step_sizes_sigma = np.array([[2,1],[1,0],[1,1],[0,1],[1,2]])) ``` The last two parts of `step_sizes_sigma` will be ignored. The reason is that the length of the default parameters of `weights_add` and `weights_mul` are both 3. ```python # librosa/core/dtw.py (def dtw) line: 171-174 if weights_add is None: weights_add = np.array([0, 0, 0]) if weights_mul is None: weights_mul = np.array([1, 1, 1]) ``` However, `zip` will cut down the extra parts in function `calc_accu_cost`. ```python # librosa/core/dtw.py (def calc_accu_cost) line: 289-290 for cur_step_idx, cur_w_add, cur_w_mul in zip(range(step_sizes_sigma.shape[0]), weights_add, weights_mul): ``` It is a test. ```python for a, b in zip(range(3), range(10)): print (a, b) ``` The output is that in Python2 or Python3: ``` (0, 0) (1, 1) (2, 2) ``` --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/librosa/librosa/594)

<!--

<!-- Instructions For Filing a Bug: https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#filing-bugs -->

#### Description

* Compute CQT.
* Display with `librosa.display.specshow()` and `y_axis='cqt_note'`
* Note axis has offset by one semitone.

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce

```Python
import librosa

cur_audio, fs = librosa.load('Systematic_Scale-C-Major_Meinard_middle.wav')
C = librosa.cqt(cur_audio, sr=fs)
librosa.display.specshow(librosa.amplitude_to_db(C, ref=np.max),
                         sr=fs, x_axis='time', y_axis='cqt_note')```
```

#### Expected Results

For my audio example, first note should be a C4.

#### Actual Results

A C4#
![screen shot 2017-06-09 at 15 06 41](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7326732/26976758-869bf1a4-4d25-11e7-9ca9-19858575c3c1.png)

I think the problem lies here:
https://github.com/librosa/librosa/blob/master/librosa/display.py#L855

Instead of
`core.cqt_frequencies(n+1, fmin=fmin, bins_per_octave=bins_per_octave)`

we need

title: Use of conjugate in stft/istft

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: discussion
labels.description: Open-ended discussion for developers and users

body:
I noticed that librosa uses the conjugate of the FFT in the stft/istft code:
```
        # RFFT and Conjugate here to match phase from DPWE code
        stft_matrix[:, bl_s:bl_t] = fft.fft(fft_window *
                                            y_frames[:, bl_s:bl_t],
                                            axis=0)[:stft_matrix.shape[0]].conj()
```
The code comments say that is "to match DPWE code", and indeed I can see that Dan's [Matlab stft.m code](http://www.ee.columbia.edu/ln/rosa/matlab/pvoc/stft.m) returns the Hermitian transpose `d(:,c) = t(1:(1+f/2))';` instead of the transpose `d(:,c) = t(1:(1+f/2)).';`, but I don't believe I've seen this convention used anywhere else.
Is there a particular reason to do so?
