title: @optional_jit fails with no parameters when numba is not available

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
[tagging @stefan-balke ]

The following code works when numba is available, but not when it isn't:
```python
@optional_jit
def some_function():
    do_some_stuff
```
However, this always works:
```python
@optional_jit(nopython=True)
def some_function():
    do_some_stuff
```
I think this means we're not creating the fall-back decorator properly; it only executes when called with parameters.  This ought to be an easy fix.

title: CQT length scale normalization

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Does this improve existing functionality?

labels.name: functionality
labels.description: Does this add new functionality?

labels.name: API change
labels.description: Does this change the behavior of existing API?

body: This PR implements #412, and a couple of bug-fixes. Summary of contents: - Added a `scale` boolean option to all CQT methods. If enabled, CQT bands are normalized by `sqrt(n[i])` where `n[i]` is the length of the `i`th filter. This is analogous to `norm='ortho'` mode in `np.fft.fft`. - Early downsampling is less aggressive by one octave. Previously, it was too aggressive, and the top-end of each octave was close to nyquist, which resulted in attenuation. - Magnitude is now continuous and approximately equal for full, hybrid, and pseudo CQT. This fixes some of the unresolved continuity errors noted in #347. - Expanded the CQT unit tests to include a white noise continuity test. Using `scale=True` means that white noise input will look like white noise output in CQT space (flat spectrum). With `scale=False` (current default), white noise in looks like `1/sqrt(f)`. `scale=True` makes an impulse look like `sqrt(f)` as opposed to constant for `scale=False`. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/librosa/librosa/417)

title: incorrect normalization in write_wav for int types

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: IO
labels.description: Issues relating to reading and writing (audio) data

body: The `write_wav` function has normalization turned on by default. However normalization does not check the `dtype` of the input and by default normalizes audio to `[-1, 1]`. The normalized range should match the the range of the data type, e.g. `[-32768, +32767]` for `int16`. The current behavior causes `scipy` to write silent audio when the `dtype` is not `float`.

title: CQT: variable_hop_response considered harmful

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
Quick addendum to #341 and #347.

@dpwe pointed out high-frequency discontinuities in CQT response to a frame-centered impulse input.  This turns out to be caused by applying `variable_hop_response` to complex-valued outputs.  VHR was useful when we were working entirely with response magntiudes, but now that CQT is complex-valued, averaging/maxing doesn't make any sense due to phase cancellation.

The fix here is to drop the variable hop response, and simply use complex FFT with the target hop length.

Fixing this will deprecate the `aggregate` parameter to `cqt` methods, which is probably a good thing.

title: fix hybrid_cqt scaling. should resolve #341

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
This fix attempts to resolve the scale discrepancy between the pseudo and full components of a hybrid_cqt.

For hop_lengths that are powers of 2, the response to an impulse is approximately constant, and the scale correction is smooth.

For odd-multiple hop-lengths, the full CQT spectrum decays but the pseudo-cqt spectrum is flat.  In these cases, we see a jump discontinuity.  I'm not sure this can be resolved directly here.

The new unit tests check the continuity of the spectrum in response to an impulse, and the total (logarithmic) deviation from the median energy.

Some additional CR from @ebattenberg and/or @dpwe would be appreciated before merging.

title: fix resampling scale for CQT

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
This PR isolates the resampling scale fix from #306 and should resolve #307.

This does change the behavior of CQT, as compared to 0.4.1 and earlier.  To recover the previous behavior, each octave should be divided by `2.0**k` where `k` index the octaves from top (0) to bottom (n_octaves - 1).

title: CQT and resampling normalization: bug or feature?

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: discussion
labels.description: Open-ended discussion for developers and users

body:
Tagging @ejhumphrey @ebattenberg @dpwe 

I've mentioned this in a few threads ( #165 #302 ), but wanted to get a focused discussion on this point ahead of 0.4.2.

The CQT method assumes that downsampling the signal and keeping the filter-bank fixed at one octave is a good approximation of applying the full filter-bank to the original signal.  This assumption only holds if the energy of the downsampled signal `y_hat` is scaled to match that of the original `y` after resampling, otherwise, you get exponentially worse approximations going down the octaves. The resamplers used in librosa (either `scipy.signal.resample` or `scikits.samplerate` sinc-interpolation) do not re-scale the output signal, and hence lead to banding artifacts in the resulting spectrograms.

My question for you lot: should we consider this a bug, and fix it in the next minor revision?  (It's at least a thinko.)  Or leave it as is to preserve backwards compatibility?  (FWIW: I think you should be able to simulate the scaling artifacts easily in post-processing, if we really feel the need to support old code.)

I have a PR out #306 that I was planning for 0.5.0 which includes a fix for this, among other changes.  However, if we decide to tag this issue as a bug, I can easily migrate the fix up to here.

title: CQT bug when hop_length != 2^k

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

labels.name: question
labels.description: Issues asking for help doing something

labels.name: testing
labels.description: Issues with our test design and continuous integration services

body:
[paging @ebattenberg ]

When the hop isn't a power of two, the bottom octave(s) can fall out of alignment.

I came across this one while experimenting with different hop lengths in CQT.  Here's a [notebook](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/bmcfee/c6aa2ab3d4823f69a4b5) to reproduce the error.

I think the error here is requiring `hop_length >= 2^k` (for `k >= num_octaves`).  Instead, 
it seems to me that the correct logic here would require hop_length to be an integer multiple of 2^k, and then require that `k >= num_octaves`.

Or perhaps there's a clever way to propagate the remainder of the hop after downsampling, rather than [flooring](https://github.com/bmcfee/librosa/blob/master/librosa/core/constantq.py#L227) as is currently done?

labels.name: bug

labels.name: question
labels.description: Issues asking for help doing something

body:
Just sanity-checking against [Scientific pitch notation](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_pitch_notation), which puts 'C4' at midi note 60 (261.63 Hz).  Librosa's octave calculation differs by one:

``` python
In [3]: librosa.hz_to_midi(261.63)
Out[3]: array([ 60.00029345])
In [4]: librosa.hz_to_note(261.63)
Out[4]: ['C5']
```

Not sure how this snuck in, but I think we should fix it before 0.4.  Anyone object?

title: decompose tests occasionally fail

The unit test for `librosa.decompose` can occasionally fail, due to the randomness in the default NMF method.

This can be circumvented by seeding the random number generator within the unit test.

title: ifgram returns negative frequencies

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
Title says it all:

``` python
>>> y, sr = librosa.load(librosa.util.example_audio_file())
>>> F, D = librosa.ifgram(y)
>>> F.size
2713175
>>> F[F < 0].size
1949
```

The negatives are huge, as well:

``` python
>>> F[F < 0]
array([ -2.236e+02,  -2.130e+02,  -4.991e-01, ...,  -1.862e+03,
        -5.777e+03,  -2.168e+03])
```

Note that `librosa.ifgram` passes regression tests against @dpwe's matlab implementation, so this is probably an algorithmic issue rather than translation.

title: Add check in estimate_tuning

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
Great library, tnx for your efforts!

In librosa.feature.estimate_tuning, the median magnitude is calculated for bins where the frequency is larger than zero: threshold = np.median(mag[pitch_mask])

In some cases, no such bins exist, which results in the method returning NaN.
Naive workaround:
if(np.count_nonzero(pitch_mask)>0):
       threshold = np.median(mag[pitch_mask])
else:
       threshold=1000.0

title: stft stride trick seem not working on an early-2013 Macbook Pro with Mavericks

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
I just got my new laptop from Adobe today and as usual I installed all the standard Python stuff. Then when I tried to run [some early demo code](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/github/dawenl/bp_nmf/blob/master/code/exp_demo.ipynb), the spectrogram I got is [wrong](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/urls/gist.githubusercontent.com/dawenl/5c698c4c62fe5eb1b927/raw/1e8f3f0feb091c6dc87d39b9f44569d8a9f4c912/wrong_stft_output): it is symmetric even it's not supposed to be and apparently it only processed half of the actual signal. 

I tried librosa v0.2.0 where the STFT was implemented in the naive way without using the stride trick and it worked fine. So I assume the problem comes from there, but I tried some simple stride examples on this Adobe laptop without problem. Both my personal laptop and Adobe one has numpy v1.8.1. I would be happy to fix it, but just before I dig into it too deep, if you guys have any idea about the possible cause, please let me know.

title: Time format in librosa.display.time_ticks()

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
The time display for "hours:minutes:seconds" format is not correct, since it didn't subtract the hours when calculating the minutes:

``` python
formatters = {'ms': lambda t: '%dms' % (1e3 * t),
              's':  lambda t: '%0.2fs' % t,
              'm':  lambda t: '%d:%02d' % ( t / 60, np.mod(t, 60)),
              'h':  lambda t: '%d:%02d:%02d' % (t / 3600, t / 60, np.mod(t, 60))}
```

So if the length of the data you want to visualize is larger than one hour, the minute part will be incorrect (off by `hours * 60`).

title: memory-limit stft

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
The vectorized stft is faster than the iterative approach, but at the expense of memory.  This is due to the pre-allocation of the intermediate windowed signal (though framing is still in place).  For very long signals, or high-resolution STFTs, this can cause a substantial memory bloat.

A better approach is to do compute the STFT in vectorized blocks, up to some configurable threshold (say, 1GB of intermediate data).

title: librosa.util.frame hemorrhages memory

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body: The trouble here is that the call to `reshape` on `y` initially over-allocates the amount of memory it will need.  The over-allocation is substantial, and probably unnecessary.  On long tracks, it can cause segfaults when the process exceeds memory limitations.

title: librosa.output.write_wav flips samples on my system

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
See the following for a simple example - synthesizing 30 samples of a sine wave, writing out, reading back in - results in large samples being flipped across the x axis.  This is a problem with write_wav, not load I believe.  As before, this may be an issue with my new install as opposed to librosa.

``` python
import librosa
import numpy as np
fs = 22050
b = np.sin(2*np.pi*np.arange(30)*1000/(1.*fs))
plt.plot(b, '.')
librosa.output.write_wav('test.wav', b, fs)
c, fs = librosa.load('test.wav', sr=fs)
plt.plot(c, 'x')
plt.ylim([-1.1, 1.1])
```

title: stft shape check

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
In `core.py`, stft checks the shape of user-specified window to make sure it's the same as `n_fft`:

``` python
if window.shape != n_fft:
    raise ValueError('Size mismatch between n_fft and window shape')
```

However, `window.shape` is apparently a tuple while `n_fft` is a number, so this will always return False even if the user-specified window is correct. `window.size` should do the job. 

This is a simple fix, but since I still haven't fully figured out how the different branches interact with each other, in order not to mess everything up, someone (@bmcfee) please fix it. 

-Dawen

where `len(y)` is 2.

title: stft/istft window type

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something doesn't work like it should

body:
When I tried to do istft on the original stft matrix to see if perfect reconstruction can be achieved, which under certain condition it should, I noticed that the window type is a little problematic: scipy.signal.hann by default will return a symmetric window, but if the window size is even, a [periodic window](https://ccrma.stanford.edu/~jos/sasp/Overlap_Add_Decomposition.html#22206) should be used for perfect reconstruction. I think Dan's code forces window size to be odd but librosa didn't do that. 

The following code will reproduce the problem:

``` python
M = 16    # window length
N = 3 * M  # the length of the signal
R = M / 2  # hop size
x = np.ones((N,))    # input a flat signal
X_sym = librosa.stft(x, n_fft=M, hop_length=R)    # use symmetric hann window
X_perc = librosa.stft(x, n_fft=M, hop_length=R, window=scipy.signal.hann(M, sym=False))    # use periodic window
x_rec_sym = librosa.istft(X_sym, n_fft=M, hop_length=R, hann_w=0)
x_rec_perc = librosa.istft(X_perc, n_fft=M, hop_length=R, hann_w=0)
subplot(311)
stem(arange(N), x)
subplot(312)
stem(arange(N), x_rec_sym)
subplot(313)
stem(arange(N), x_rec_perc)
tight_layout()
```

Periodic window gives perfect reconstruction except for the first and last half of the window which is as expected, but symmetric window doesn't. 

A simple fix would be to change all the window with sym=False and this won't affect odd number window size.
